randoop
Interface Check

All Superinterfaces:
Serializable
All Known Implementing Classes:
ExpectedExceptionChecker, ForbiddenExceptionChecker, ObjectCheck
public interface Check
extends Serializable

A correctness check performed on some aspect of a unit test's execution. Examples include assertions, calls to invariant or "checkRep" methods, or try-catch clauses that check for expected exceptions.

Check objects are inserted as a decorations on specific indices of an ExecutableSequence. Thus, a check is always associated with a specific statement in a sequence.

A check may require some code to be emitted before and/or after the statement is printed. For example, a checker that inserts the assertion " x != null" for a statement "Foo var0 = m()" need only emit the assertion code after the statement. A checker that surrounds the statement with a try-catch clause to test for an expected exception needs to emit the try part of the clause before the statement, and the catch part after the statement (see ExpectedExceptionChecker, for example).

A check must implement two methods that specify the code to be emitted before and/or after a statement in a Sequence is executed.

Checks should be Serializable so that an ExecutableSequence can be serialized along with its associated checks.

Method Summary
 String get_value()
          Return a short string that can be used to uniquely identify this check.
 String toCodeStringPostStatement()
          Return a string of Java source code to be emitted after a statement containing this check.
 String toCodeStringPreStatement()
          Return a string of Java source code to be emitted before a statement containing this check.
